posts.title: Complete Guide to Exterior Painting in the GTA
posts.excerpt: Everything you need to know about preparing, painting, and protecting your home's exterior in Ontario's climate.
posts.content:
## Why Exterior Painting Matters

Your home's exterior paint does more than make it look beautiful—it's the first line of defense against Ontario's harsh weather.

### Climate Challenges in the GTA

- **Temperature Swings**: From -25°C winters to 30°C+ summers
- **UV Exposure**: Intense summer sun causes fading and chalking
- **Moisture**: Rain, snow, and humidity threaten paint integrity
- **Freeze-Thaw Cycles**: Can crack inadequate paint systems

## Choosing the Right Paint

### Exterior Paint Types

- **100% Acrylic Latex**: Best for most siding materials, excellent flexibility
- **Alkyd (Oil-Based)**: Ideal for metal surfaces and doors
- **Elastomeric**: Maximum protection for stucco and masonry

## Best Time to Paint Exterior

Spring (May-June) and Fall (September-October) offer ideal conditions:

- Moderate temperatures (15-25°C)
- Lower humidity
- Stable weather patterns

Avoid painting when:
- Temperature below 10°C
- Rain forecasted within 24 hours
- High winds
- Direct sun on fresh paint

posts.title: Stucco vs EIFS: What You Need to Know
posts.excerpt: Understanding the differences between traditional stucco and modern EIFS systems to make the right choice for your project.
posts.content:
## Traditional Stucco

Traditional stucco is a cement-based exterior finish that's been used for centuries.

### Advantages

- **Durability**: Can last 50+ years with proper maintenance
- **Fire Resistance**: Non-combustible material
- **Low Maintenance**: Periodic cleaning and sealing
- **Breathability**: Allows moisture vapor to escape

### Disadvantages

- **Cracking**: Can develop cracks from settling
- **Moisture**: Requires proper installation to prevent water intrusion
- **Cost**: More expensive than some alternatives

## EIFS (Exterior Insulation Finish System)

Modern EIFS combines insulation with a synthetic finish coat.

### Advantages

- **Energy Efficiency**: R-value of 4-5.6 per inch
- **Design Flexibility**: Can mimic many textures
- **Lightweight**: Reduces structural load
- **Water Management**: Modern systems include drainage

### Disadvantages

- **Impact Resistance**: Can be damaged by impacts
- **Installation**: Requires experienced contractors
- **Maintenance**: Regular inspections needed

posts.title: Property Manager's Guide to Building Maintenance
posts.excerpt: Essential maintenance strategies to protect property value and keep tenants happy.
posts.content:
## Preventive Maintenance Schedule

### Quarterly Inspections

- **Exterior**: Check for cracks, peeling paint, damaged siding
- **Common Areas**: Evaluate hallways, lobbies, amenity spaces
- **Parking**: Inspect coatings, line striping, drainage

### Annual Projects

- **Touch-Up Painting**: High-traffic areas
- **Caulking & Sealing**: Windows, doors, expansion joints
- **Power Washing**: Building exterior, walkways

## Budgeting for Maintenance

Typical annual maintenance costs:

- **Painting**: $2-4 per square foot
- **Exterior Repairs**: 1-3% of building value
- **Emergency Fund**: 5-10% of maintenance budget

## Tenant Communication

### Best Practices

- **Advance Notice**: Give 72 hours minimum
- **Clear Timeline**: Start and completion dates
- **Point of Contact**: Dedicated project manager
- **Updates**: Regular progress communications
